ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob Buchkowski
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Robert Buchkowski

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Robert always had a great disposition to help and to explain difficult concepts patiently and kindly. He was a great TA!

Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Clearly explains concepts, very available, personable, has clear mastery of the material and is happy to meet students where they are based on preparation and work with them patiently to bring them to speed.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob was an excellent TA, he knows the material well and gives clear help and is very accessible.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  He was an excellent TA. His biggest strength is that he made the concepts simpler and easier to understand.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Eli is a great professor, he's very supportive of student's needs and has a great disposition to help us. My only constructive criticism would be to ask him to be less obvious in showing when he's disappointed whenever he asks a question to the class and we fail to answer it correctly.

Q11/12 Eli is very knowledgeable about the subject material and usually conveys concepts very clearly. Sometimes more examples would be helpful. Lots of little examples might prove more effective than one really big proof of concept which often confuses the class...

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I really enjoyed reading E and the two book club sessions. Also, I think that including R as one of the tools we are taught is great. My only suggestion would be to have at least two or three sessions in the computer lab to play a bit more with the software; I think this would be specially useful for those of us who were not familiar with it before the class.
The format of the homework -- three chances -- properly emphasizes the learning process.

The associated historical context readings Experience of the professor both in the theoretical and applied uses of the math we were discussing The approach of the material from various angles and in order to meet the learning styles of different students High relevance connections of all topics--allowed us to understand the fun and elegance in the math because it was also so clearly important and tangible the problem sets were challenging but extremely fair: I felt like they built very reasonably off of what we learned in class and then concretely demonstrated the applications and connections to the word problems/real world contexts

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The online discussion on Canvass on the book was not great. I think this kind of book is not conducive for a lively online debate. If I had to choose over reading E or having an online discussion, I would eliminate the latter and keep the former. Also, doing more practical exercises in class would be helpful to demonstrate the usefulness of the concepts we were learning.
More frequent tie-ins between the concepts being learned and the real world scenarios to which they are applicable.

The second half of the course maintained the breakneck speed of the first half, which was I think where difficulty arose because it was material that was more likely to have not been encountered by students before this course. Thus, we were learning the most advanced and complicated material during the busiest part of the semester, and were most likely to have not encountered it yet. I think that this is relatively inevitable, but maybe providing more background materials (more applied examples of ODE!) would at least mitigate the trickiness?

The course was a little front loaded on calculus. In the future, an online interactive review of calc could occur simultaneously with the material in the course that was most new and useful (linear algebra/ ODE and constrained optimization). More focus on these later topics would strengthen the overall value of the course. Also, the statistics and probability review was amazing. Integrating the math concepts we learned into these disciplines I think was one of the most useful things I learned all semester and this part of the course could definitely be built on. More use of R would be really great. I could imagine offering this same course, but with an optional 4th credit that integrated R into the course material with a 1 or 2 hour lab section each week. This could be great!
There are to many topics for one semester of class making the pace to fast and the professor to rush over some of them.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It could be improved with more lab sessions.
NA
Yes. The sections were useful to fully understand the lectures and do the assignments.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Fantastic preparation for future work in ecological science: some concepts and strategies I will use directly in my research, others I encounter frequently in papers and readings, and am able to understand more thoroughly because of this class.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: After a first year of frustration with mathematical concepts, I wanted to fill in the gaps in my knowledge with this course.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, they even surpassed them.
Absolutely. I learned more than I expected and improved my mathematical fluency far beyond what I thought would be possible in a semester
The course might have been a little oversold to me. I was expecting to get through the review of derivatives and integrals more quickly...

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: There were no formal groups, but I often studied and troubleshot with other students, and the discussions of "how our brains worked" was HUGE in my understanding of the material

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: To not be scared by the apparent complexity of the concepts reviewed. I mean, yes, we deal with many difficult topics and this is an intensive course on material that otherwise would take more than two semesters to cover, but the benefits are worth it and the help that both the Professor and the TA provide makes everything easier.
I would urge students to read the syllabus carefully before signing up for the course. It is not a "remedial math for masters students" course -- it is fast-paced and challenging.
Be ready to put in the time!
